content.raw:
Just to confirm, which topics do we want to suppress from the simulation? From my understanding, we should suppress:

* All `/gazebo` namespace topics
* `/joint_states`
* Probably the `/vrx/.../shuffle` topics? \(not sure what they do, apparently from `rostopic info` they are std\_msgs/Empty. I think it just shuffles objects if msg is published, so this should be suppressed\)

We may be able to use [https://github.com/osrf/ariac-gazebo\_ros\_pkgs/commits/ariac-network-melodic](https://github.com/osrf/ariac-gazebo_ros_pkgs/commits/ariac-network-melodic) directly, as the suppressed topics are very similar.

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/6zzkq96/images/1027451384-Rostopic_List_from_Sandisland.png)
‌

_Figure 1:_ `rostopic list` _from_ `sandisland.launch`

---

‌

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/6zzkq96/images/952272253-Rostopic_list_from_VRX.png)
‌

_Figure 2:_ `rostopic list` _from_ `vrx.launch`
content.html:
Just to confirm, which topics do we want to suppress from the simulation? From my understanding, we should suppress:

  • All /gazebo namespace topics
  • /joint_states
  • Probably the /vrx/.../shuffle topics? (not sure what they do, apparently from rostopic info they are std_msgs/Empty. I think it just shuffles objects if msg is published, so this should be suppressed)

We may be able to use https://github.com/osrf/ariac-gazebo_ros_pkgs/commits/ariac-network-melodic directly, as the suppressed topics are very similar.

‌

Figure 1: rostopic list from sandisland.launch

‌

‌

Figure 2: rostopic list from vrx.launch

content.raw: It looks like I should only be setting `ROS_IP` or `ROS_HOSTNAME`. For our case, which should we set? If hostname, does it matter what names I choose? If IP address, how do I choose an IP Address? I am still new to these network topics.
content.html: It looks like I should only be setting ROS_IP or ROS_HOSTNAME. For our case, which should we set? If hostname, does it matter what names I choose? If IP address, how do I choose an IP Address? I am still new to these network topics.

content.raw:
[http://wiki.ros.org/ROS/Tutorials/MultipleMachines](http://wiki.ros.org/ROS/Tutorials/MultipleMachines)

_If something in the above sequence didn't work, the cause is likely in your network configuration. See_ [_ROS/NetworkSetup_](http://wiki.ros.org/ROS/NetworkSetup) _and_ [_ROS/Troubleshooting_](http://wiki.ros.org/ROS/Troubleshooting) _for configuration requirements and troubleshooting tips._

_One common trap is the missing define of ROS\_IP on the machine, where talker.py is running._

_check it with: echo $ROS\_IP_

_If you dont't define ROS\_IP, then rostopic info will show indeed the proper connections of publisher and listener, but rostopic echo will be empty. You will see no TX-traffic on LAN, on machine with talker. First, after defining ROS\_IP with proper IP-address \( export ROS\_IP=machine\_ip\_addr\) you will see trafic on LAN and the listener.py will show received data._
content.html:
http://wiki.ros.org/ROS/Tutorials/MultipleMachines

If something in the above sequence didn't work, the cause is likely in your network configuration. See ROS/NetworkSetup and ROS/Troubleshooting for configuration requirements and troubleshooting tips.

One common trap is the missing define of ROS_IP on the machine, where talker.py is running.

check it with: echo $ROS_IP

If you dont't define ROS_IP, then rostopic info will show indeed the proper connections of publisher and listener, but rostopic echo will be empty. You will see no TX-traffic on LAN, on machine with talker. First, after defining ROS_IP with proper IP-address ( export ROS_IP=machine_ip_addr) you will see trafic on LAN and the listener.py will show received data.

content.raw:
[http://wiki.ros.org/ROS/EnvironmentVariables](http://wiki.ros.org/ROS/EnvironmentVariables)

## ROS\_IP/ROS\_HOSTNAME

`ROS_IP` _and_ `ROS_HOSTNAME` _are optional environment variable that sets the declared network address of a ROS_ [_Node_](http://wiki.ros.org/Node) _or tool. The options are mutually exclusive, if both are set_ `ROS_HOSTNAME` _will take precedence. Use_ `ROS_IP` _if you are specifying an IP address, and_ `ROS_HOSTNAME` _if you are specifying a host name. When a ROS component reports a URI to the master or other components, this value will be used. This setting is only needed in situations where you have multiple addresses for a computer and need to force ROS to a particular one._

_With the exception of 'localhost', it does not affect the actual bound address as ROS components bind to all available network interfaces. If the value is set to localhost, the ROS component will bind only to the loopback interface. This will prevent remote components from being able to talk to your local component._
content.html:
http://wiki.ros.org/ROS/EnvironmentVariables

ROS_IP/ROS_HOSTNAME

ROS_IP and ROS_HOSTNAME are optional environment variable that sets the declared network address of a ROS Node or tool. The options are mutually exclusive, if both are set ROS_HOSTNAME will take precedence. Use ROS_IP if you are specifying an IP address, and ROS_HOSTNAME if you are specifying a host name. When a ROS component reports a URI to the master or other components, this value will be used. This setting is only needed in situations where you have multiple addresses for a computer and need to force ROS to a particular one.

With the exception of 'localhost', it does not affect the actual bound address as ROS components bind to all available network interfaces. If the value is set to localhost, the ROS component will bind only to the loopback interface. This will prevent remote components from being able to talk to your local component.

content.raw: I am not super confident about how ROS\_MASTER\_URI, ROS\_HOSTNAME, ROS\_IP, and GAZEBO\_IP work. I used [https://answers.ros.org/question/228292/exposing-ros-containers-to-host-machine/](https://answers.ros.org/question/228292/exposing-ros-containers-to-host-machine/) and [https://answers.ros.org/question/298602/how-to-have-topics-publish-and-subscribe-both-ways-between-host-and-docker-container/](https://answers.ros.org/question/298602/how-to-have-topics-publish-and-subscribe-both-ways-between-host-and-docker-container/) for reference. Initially, when I started the server and competition containers, the competition could see the topics \(\`rostopic list\` showed topics from the simulator\), but if I published to /left\_thrust\_cmd from the competition container, the server container was not seeing it. Changing the ROS\_MASTER\_URIs made it work.
content.html: I am not super confident about how ROS_MASTER_URI, ROS_HOSTNAME, ROS_IP, and GAZEBO_IP work. I used https://answers.ros.org/question/228292/exposing-ros-containers-to-host-machine/ and https://answers.ros.org/question/298602/how-to-have-topics-publish-and-subscribe-both-ways-between-host-and-docker-container/ for reference. Initially, when I started the server and competition containers, the competition could see the topics (`rostopic list` showed topics from the simulator), but if I published to /left_thrust_cmd from the competition container, the server container was not seeing it. Changing the ROS_MASTER_URIs made it work.

content.raw:
**Progress**

I have made some solid progress this week.

* `./kill_containers.bash` to kill created containers from `./run_trial.bash`
* Example Docker file for competitors `vrx_competitor/Dockerfile`
* `./vrx_network.bash` to create a common network for containers
* `./vrx_server/build_image.bash` to create an image for the server

`./run_trial <team_name> <trial_name>` is  the high level script that 

* Checks for valid input
* Creates a log folder on the host
* Checks for valid config .yaml files
* Kills old running containers
* Starts a network
* Runs `./vrx_server/run_container.bash`, which creates the server container and runs `vrx_server/vrx-server/run_vrx_task.bash`
* Runs the example competition containers, which currently publishes a left\_thrust\_cmd value and echos imu/data
* Runs this for a certain amount of time before saving log files, killing containers, and exiting

‌

**Instructions to Test**

1. Go to the root directory of this repo `cd vrx-docker`
2. Build the server image `./vrx_server/build_image.bash` \(may take up to 25 min with bad wifi, working to reduce this\)
3. Build the example competition image \(based on [https://docs.docker.com/samples/library/ros/#networks](https://docs.docker.com/samples/library/ros/#networks)\) `docker build --tag ros:ros-tutorials ./vrx_competitor`
4. Run the example trial with an example team `./run_trial.bash example_team example_trial`

To explore the docker containers being made, run `docker container ls` and to look inside a container you can run `docker exec -it <container_id> bash`, eg `docker exec -it vrx-server-system bash`
content.html:
Progress

I have made some solid progress this week.

  • ./kill_containers.bash to kill created containers from ./run_trial.bash
  • Example Docker file for competitors vrx_competitor/Dockerfile
  • ./vrx_network.bash to create a common network for containers
  • ./vrx_server/build_image.bash to create an image for the server

./run_trial <team_name> <trial_name> is the high level script that

  • Checks for valid input
  • Creates a log folder on the host
  • Checks for valid config .yaml files
  • Kills old running containers
  • Starts a network
  • Runs ./vrx_server/run_container.bash, which creates the server container and runs vrx_server/vrx-server/run_vrx_task.bash
  • Runs the example competition containers, which currently publishes a left_thrust_cmd value and echos imu/data
  • Runs this for a certain amount of time before saving log files, killing containers, and exiting

‌

Instructions to Test

  1. Go to the root directory of this repo cd vrx-docker
  2. Build the server image ./vrx_server/build_image.bash (may take up to 25 min with bad wifi, working to reduce this)
  3. Build the example competition image (based on https://docs.docker.com/samples/library/ros/#networks) docker build --tag ros:ros-tutorials ./vrx_competitor
  4. Run the example trial with an example team ./run_trial.bash example_team example_trial

To explore the docker containers being made, run docker container ls and to look inside a container you can run docker exec -it <container_id> bash, eg docker exec -it vrx-server-system bash

I am currently trying to run the `generate_wamv.launch` and `generate_worlds.launch` launches before the simulation, but I am getting strange issues such as:

`run_id on parameter server does not match declared run_id: 839d8b68-92db-11e9-8a58-0242ac120003 vs 839aa240-92db-11e9-89a9-0242ac120003`

`what():  boost: mutex lock failed in pthread_mutex_lock: Invalid argument`

`load_parameters: unable to set parameters (last param was [None]): [Errno 111] Connection refused`

I believe they are all related, but I still need to look into it.

content.raw:
**Instructions**

1. Go to root directory \(vrx-docker\)
2. Create directories for teams and trials `mkdir -p team_config/myteam` and `mkdir -p trial_config/mytrial`
3. Build image for server \(may take up to 20 min, should finalize image details and push image to dockerhub\) `./vrx_server/build_image.bash`
4. Run `./run_trial.bash`, which will run the vrx\_server with the simulation

From how I understand it, the simulation should end when the trial is over \(when topic `/vrx/task/info` has `timed_out: True`\). What is the correct way of shutting it down?

ARIAC has something like 

```
# Run the task.
ARIAC_EXIT_ON_COMPLETION=1 rosrun osrf_gear gear.py --no-gui -v -f $1$2
```

But it is not clear how this works.
content.html:
Instructions

  1. Go to root directory (vrx-docker)
  2. Create directories for teams and trials mkdir -p team_config/myteam and mkdir -p trial_config/mytrial
  3. Build image for server (may take up to 20 min, should finalize image details and push image to dockerhub) ./vrx_server/build_image.bash
  4. Run ./run_trial.bash, which will run the vrx_server with the simulation

From how I understand it, the simulation should end when the trial is over (when topic /vrx/task/info has timed_out: True). What is the correct way of shutting it down?

ARIAC has something like 

# Run the task.
ARIAC_EXIT_ON_COMPLETION=1 rosrun osrf_gear gear.py --no-gui -v -f $1$2

But it is not clear how this works.

content.raw:
**High level plan**:

1. Create a `Dockerfile` for making the `vrx_server` image. It should have every dependency needed to start the simulation and log results. \(later, will make change to use different branch of Gazebo for not exposing simulator topics\)
2. Setup network connection such that `vrx_server` image can be published to from another container
3. Setup an example Docker image for controlling the simulated boat \(eg. just tell the boat to go straight forwards\) that teams will need to supply.
4. Make the Gazebo fork to limit exposed ROS topics
5. Create scripts to generate videos
6. Make scripts to do this for all teams \(connect the scripts together\)

**Progress**

So far, I have been able to do 1 \(though I have some questions to make sure I am on the right track\). I am a bit stuck on 2 right now, as I do not have a good understanding about how to set things up.

I am still quite new to Docker, so I have some questions I will list below. I will keep working on them and trying to figure them out as much as I can myself \(mostly writing it here for myself\), but if you can give me some guidance on this, that would be really appreciated.

**Questions for 1**

1. In the `Dockerfile` for the `vrx_server` image, I based some of the dependencies on the `docker/Dockerfile` in the vrx repository. However, it has numerous dependencies that I believe are only for development, which aren’t needed \(eg. git, vim, etc.\) Is there a clean, simple way I can figure out which ones are needed and which aren’t for the purpose of running the simulator on the server side \(faster than simply removing and seeing if things break\) [#!/osrf/vrx/src/default/docker/Dockerfile](#!/osrf/vrx/src/default/docker/Dockerfile) \(some things like joy\_teleop are obviously not needed, but I feel we might need ros-$\{DIST\}-velodyne-simulator or ros-$\{DIST\}-robot-state-publisher\)
2. More of a high level question. Could I simply follow the steps of the tutorial _Install on Host_ [#!/osrf/vrx/wiki/tutorials/SystemSetupInstall](#!/osrf/vrx/wiki/tutorials/SystemSetupInstall)? What differences are there between that and the current docker setup? [#!/osrf/vrx/src/default/docker/Dockerfile](#!/osrf/vrx/src/default/docker/Dockerfile)
3. `docker/keys` contains and old `ros.key` that no longer works. Related to [[http://answers.ros.org/question/325039/apt-update-fails-cannot-install-pkgs-key-not-working/](http://answers.ros.org/question/325039/apt-update-fails-cannot-install-pkgs-key-not-working/)](http://answers.ros.org/question/325039/apt-update-fails-cannot-install-pkgs-key-not-working). Is there a reason why we store the keys, instead of using `wget http://packages.osrfoundation.org/gazebo.key` or `wget http://packages.ros.org/ros.key`
4. There is some nvidia-docker related setup in the other Dockerfile. Will we need this for running simulations \(I am guessing yes for better simulation performance\)
5. Are we supporting Gazebo 7 or ROS Kinetic, or just Gazebo 9 and ROS Melodic?
6. I will share these questions and more when I make a PR, but I just wanted to write it out and maybe get a quick answer on some parts if obvious.

**Questions for 2**

1. I understand that we need to set up a network for the containers to communicate. However, I don’t understand some details about what IP Addresses to use, which IP addresses are available, creating subnets, what do do if I get errors like

`Pool overlaps with other one on this address space,`

`Error response from daemon: Invalid address 172.18.0.22: It does not belong to any of this network's subnets.`

`Error response from daemon: user specified IP address is supported only when connecting to networks with user configured subnets.`

**Questions for 3**

* The new plan is to, instead of have teams give us files `build_team_system.bash` and `run_team_system.bash`, they can give us URL to image \(that already does the part of `build_team_system.bash`\). But would they still need to supply a separate `run_team_system.bash` to be run from inside the container, or should their image both build and run the system?
content.html:
High level plan:

  1. Create a Dockerfile for making the vrx_server image. It should have every dependency needed to start the simulation and log results. (later, will make change to use different branch of Gazebo for not exposing simulator topics)
  2. Setup network connection such that vrx_server image can be published to from another container
  3. Setup an example Docker image for controlling the simulated boat (eg. just tell the boat to go straight forwards) that teams will need to supply.
  4. Make the Gazebo fork to limit exposed ROS topics
  5. Create scripts to generate videos
  6. Make scripts to do this for all teams (connect the scripts together)

Progress

So far, I have been able to do 1 (though I have some questions to make sure I am on the right track). I am a bit stuck on 2 right now, as I do not have a good understanding about how to set things up.

I am still quite new to Docker, so I have some questions I will list below. I will keep working on them and trying to figure them out as much as I can myself (mostly writing it here for myself), but if you can give me some guidance on this, that would be really appreciated.

Questions for 1

  1. In the Dockerfile for the vrx_server image, I based some of the dependencies on the docker/Dockerfile in the vrx repository. However, it has numerous dependencies that I believe are only for development, which aren’t needed (eg. git, vim, etc.) Is there a clean, simple way I can figure out which ones are needed and which aren’t for the purpose of running the simulator on the server side (faster than simply removing and seeing if things break) #!/osrf/vrx/src/default/docker/Dockerfile (some things like joy_teleop are obviously not needed, but I feel we might need ros-${DIST}-velodyne-simulator or ros-${DIST}-robot-state-publisher)
  2. More of a high level question. Could I simply follow the steps of the tutorial Install on Host #!/osrf/vrx/wiki/tutorials/SystemSetupInstall? What differences are there between that and the current docker setup? #!/osrf/vrx/src/default/docker/Dockerfile
  3. docker/keys contains and old ros.key that no longer works. Related to [http://answers.ros.org/question/325039/apt-update-fails-cannot-install-pkgs-key-not-working/](http://answers.ros.org/question/325039/apt-update-fails-cannot-install-pkgs-key-not-working/). Is there a reason why we store the keys, instead of using wget http://packages.osrfoundation.org/gazebo.key or wget http://packages.ros.org/ros.key
  4. There is some nvidia-docker related setup in the other Dockerfile. Will we need this for running simulations (I am guessing yes for better simulation performance)
  5. Are we supporting Gazebo 7 or ROS Kinetic, or just Gazebo 9 and ROS Melodic?
  6. I will share these questions and more when I make a PR, but I just wanted to write it out and maybe get a quick answer on some parts if obvious.

Questions for 2

  1. I understand that we need to set up a network for the containers to communicate. However, I don’t understand some details about what IP Addresses to use, which IP addresses are available, creating subnets, what do do if I get errors like

Pool overlaps with other one on this address space,

Error response from daemon: Invalid address 172.18.0.22: It does not belong to any of this network's subnets.

Error response from daemon: user specified IP address is supported only when connecting to networks with user configured subnets.

But would they still need to supply a separate run_team_system.bash to be run from inside the container, or should their image both build and run the system?
